column4: A fun mini golf game. pretty good and somewhat addictive. It has multiplayer, but unfortunatly only local, online multiplay would be nice so that you could play against friends online.
As crazy golf games go this takes some beating, and it is amazing with nividia 3d vision. Well worth a download.

This game you only want to buy it if you are planning on having friends or family over. There is no online multiplayer, only local. The last thing I like to do in this game is to learn all the hole and ones and then play my friends without telling them where they are lol.

Like mini golf? Well then you're going to love this game. It does a great job simulating it with some good humor , this game is great for all ages. The holes to be played aren't too hard, and its just a great casual game that is fun all around. Highly recommended!
Why is this hole a Par 2? Why am I at +38? Why am I still here? WHY DOES THE BALL ALWAYS STOP JUST SHORT OF THE HOLE? WHY AM I RECOMMENDING THIS GAME?!
this game is very good and have lot of fun
IT'S 3D GASP IT'S ULTRA GASP IT'S MINIGOLF GASP IT'S AN ADVENTURE... ...AND IT'S DELUXE!... ...But it's a cool game...

This is the coolest game that I've ever played. Me and Joe just spent 115 minutes in one session playing the local multiplayer, and i can say, without a doubt, that this is my alltime favourite game and i recomend it to anybody that has friends.   21/10
Basically the most amazing game ever.
UPDATE 9/28: revived by necromancer. game is OK, but I definitely had more adventures in the hellish afterworld than I did playing Mini Golf in Mini Golf Adventures  UPDATE: still dead  i'm dead
Good, fun game to play to cool off from all that pwning you've been doing!

its a nice game i would like too play the followerupper on pc.  but its not worth 10 euros. paid the full 10 and got 4 hours of play maybe its more worth if you got multiplayer but for a solo game its not worth it and difficulty sucks, first time i got +37 on the campain and secon -9 so ofc its all about learning the maps but the ai dont adjust and you cant change diff, the ai alwyas end up with 10-20+
Another Dejobaan title that starts with Aa... or something similar to keep it high on a list alphabetically. This was fun for about two levels and then it quickly loses any luster.
Can't recommend it for the sole reason that the semi-sequel AAAAA for the awesome is the exact same game but has more levels.

I really enjoyed this game, mostly because of its originality; most games aren’t about skydiving off buildings. I’ve come back to play it for a while, I want to say I’ve got about 2 hours into it. At this point, I need to replay some levels to get more points to unlock more stages, so I doubt I’ll play it again and beat it, but it was fun for the low price of whatever I got it for. Overall, I would recommend this if it’s cheap enough.
Thanks to   AaAaAA!!! A Reckless Disregard for Gravity   I got all the hugs and kisses I never got as a child!

Clever title, clever mechanics, clever bits of story/extra material.   There isn't too much more that's good about the game. While it's fun to play for a bunch of the levels, it slowly decends to a kind of perfectionist/point ♥♥♥♥♥ style of gameplay where you can only advance if you play previous levels to excess to get more teeth (in-game currency) and allow you to unlock more levels. I wouldn't mind so much if the teeth values for most levels were significantly lowered, but having to play and 5-star the easiest level 200 times to unlock the next level is tedious. Other than the occasional ARG content, it's not worth playing past a certain point mid-way through what's available and leaves much to be desired.  If you really want to play it: unlock all the little extra videos/audio content first, then see how far you can get. The extra little tidbits are genuinely hilarous by virtue of surreal humor.   Generally: give this a miss.
Make sure to base jump safely, taking all the usual precautions, or you might contract a disease.

halfway decent game, worthy of about two to ten hours of playtime, possibly more for those with ocd.  however, this was dejobann's last finished product and they have been selling only incomplete games for the last six years.  this game isn't so bad but it is not worth more than a dollar.  i wouldn't support dejobann games if i were you because they stopped completing projects about six years ago but they sell them all for full price.  this game may be a finished product but everything they have done since is nothing but one rip off after another.  beware: the developers/publishers of this product are robbers. no other product that they are selling is worth buying. and this one is over priced even at 80% discount.  you have been warned.

First of all: The title is awesome and it's a great example for the kind of humor that Dejobaan Games stands for. Now, what is this game about? There's no real story to speak of. You are some guy, who does BASE jumps from very large buildings. Don't mistake this game for some sort of simulation though, you don't just jump off of real skyscrapers, but rather interesting and fictional constructions and there is quite an array of things to do on your way down. The game is very highscore oriented, so the most replay value comes out of reaching the best score you possibly can on each level and while that could sound dull to some, I really enjoyed playing it.

My Take: A frantic paced game where you attempt to reach perfection on each level and will not rest until you have five stars. Rude gesture to all the protesters out there.   Graphics: Simple polygons, but everything is distinctive enough that you can make out what's what during high speeds.  Sound: Enough entertaining noises to distract you from how annoyed you are.  Music: Not good enough to listen to on its own, but well suits the pace of the game.  Controls: Standard look and movement bindings, but I should figure out better bindings for the other actions. I end up accidentally pressing a wrong key at inopportune times.  Did I Finish It: Not 100%, but I got to the end.  Will I Play it Again: Depends on how much content is in AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!!, which I have yet to play. It's is supposed to have the same levels remastered, so I'm going to say no.  Should You Buy It: If the above holds true, they're the same price so don't bother.

AaAaAA!!! is a strange and unusual game. The premise being simple, score points by being wreckles while you base jump from floating structures. The gameplay is simple enough, control your decent, gain as many points as possible by 'hugging' and 'kissing' strucutres, hitting scoreplates and flipping off protesters.  Part of AaAaAA!!!'s charm is that it's completely tongue-in-cheek as far as 'the man' goes. It's a strange game that no one else has really managed to pull off with a correct mix of apathy for political agendas.  Even the title theme gives a good hint as to the attitude of the game. While it may be oler, it's still a great experience to hop on every once in awhile and stands out as a shining unique experience.

Great music, good idea behind the game but hard to master.  Why? Because if you want to make good scores, you have to be precise and avoid crashing on the buildings.  This game is about jumping from the top of a building (or a mountain or anything else) and to pass near every obstacle, to make a tag, to flip the bird or to make a cool gesture, to break plates with points on them, etc etc..  The graphics are good but the real strong point of this game is the music. Dat soundtrack.  Anyway, I really enjoyed that UFO from Dejobaan... if anything, it's thanks to Aaaaa that I played other games by them like Drunken Robot Pornography or The Wonderful End of the World.  Really recommended for fun.
if you contemplate suicide. this game is not for you.
The greatest 'slamming into everything' simulator ever.
A definitely unique and fun game. Difficult to fully complete, though.
not bad for the price. fast and addictive. it makes you want to replay the level over and over again.
I love it. It's a nice adrenaline rush with good difficulty and a quick reset. Also, it's zainy... TEETH!

I must say this game isn't bad at all. Think of it as a bungee jumping game where it focuses on you falling down and touching surface for extra points. You earn currency to unlock different stages as well. Although, I do wish there were more achievements, because there isn't much...

Pretty crappy. It doesn't let me change the resolution (Which would have been fine if it didn't fail to run properly at my normal nvidia surround resolutions), and it doesn't let you change the keyboard layouts (which would have been fine if it didn't introduce the grafitti action on a ♥♥♥♥ed up hand-contorting key).  So way to go, developers, you showed us how pointlessly anti-configuration you were for no god damned reason. Hope you're proud of your perplexing design decision because it ♥♥♥♥ed me up.  As for the game itself, some levels have a bit of a super meat boy vibe of short levels with challenging manuvering, but sometimes they make the levels long so it's hard to practice them, especially the end of the level because it's hard to get to it. Also it's a little needlessly unforgiving, such as falling on a 1 degree plane counting as falling onto flat ground, and catching the very corners of things should damage you sure but it just anihilates you instantly.  Another really messed up thing is that they're offering a one-time-only achievement. That's right, play now or forever have an empty slot in your achievement list. That's some really epic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Am I the only one who is annoyed as ♥♥♥♥ by that?

Motion sickness, the game.   The title of the game is accurate. There's not a whole lot to say here - it's a well designed, simple concept that's extremely fun. I don't see myself playing this to the point of obsession, but I will definitely play until I unlock everything and see what else I can do with it.   For those of you who are like me, and entirely too afraid to actually participate in extreme sports like base jumping, this will confirm your belief that you're really not cut out for it. You will be perfectly satisfied to sit in your chair, breathe in through your nose, out through your mouth, and imagine yourself floating to the ceiling.   A fun little game that doesn't take itself too seriously, and has enough silly humor to make you smile - note that you won't laugh uproariously, but I don't believe that was the point of this, anyway.   Gameplay is top notch, soundtrack is fun and funny, and I will definitely enjoy any time period in which I play this game, but I seriously doubt I will get addicted to it. One of those rare gems that's worth anyone's time, even iff you just have a few minutes to kill. I, personally, enjoy games that don't require a huge time investment in order to understand what they're about and have fun with them, and this is definitely the type where your boredom will die for a bit.   Plus, after you play for an hour or so you'll exit and still feel like you're playing it.   Neat. 8/10.  (Small edit: I mean it's not very addictive. I meant to say that it was fun, but I don't see myself getting addicted to it. Fixed.)

A lot of people seem to like this. I have no idea why. It a freefalling game where you have to do 'stunts' to gain points really. Except, it doesn't look like a freefalling game. Yes, you have the feeling you're falling down, but that's it really. It's all in first person perspective so there's no actual character involved as well. The idea is cool, but its execution is kind of poor. It would've been so much cooler to have a realistic freefalling game. Like the realism of Mirror's Edge and the freefalling/parachute gameplay of Just Cause 2. But that's all just in hindsight. So all in all; it's ok. There aren't a lot of games with this sort of gameplay so I can't really recommend any better alternatives.  [Rating: 70/100]
One of the best falling simulators I've ever played.
A strange little game I picked up years ago to tick an objective off one of the Steam events. I haven't touched it since... and from what I hear, neither have the developers.

' A Reckless Disregard for Gravity ' is a game based on a simple concept: jump off a high point, do some sick tricks to earn points, and land on the ground safely. Despite many positive aspects, the game is marred by several technical and aesthetic choices made by the developers.    The Good:    * Unique use of humor.  * Excellent sound track and sound effects.  * The base-jumping mechanic is a new, innovate way of playing games. It is a joy to jump from your starting point and hear the rush of the wind blow across your avatar's ears.  * Flight controls are good enough to seem realistic but forgiving enough to let you make a few mistakes and have fun.   * Plenty of unique ways to score points: getting close to objects, staying close to objects, giving spectators a thumbs-up or an obscene gesture, and spraypainting graffiti were all things I found within my first hour or two of play.    The Bad:    * For the world's first base-jumping game, the game feels remarkably NOT like base-jumping. Rather than zooming along the side of tall skyscrapers and landing on the ground, the player instead navigates an obstacle course of abstract, floating blocks that stand to 'represent' buildings and lands on a final circular block that is meant to represent the ground. If the player overshoots 'the ground,' he continues to fall. Yes, you can actually miss the ground. Interestingly, the levels that feature base-jumping off a mountain feature a well-modeled and detailed mountain that actually resembles something like a real mountain. (If you are going to use aestheticized shapes to represent real-world objects, why not do it consistently?)  * Every aspect of the game, from the UI to the action portion, looks and feels like a first-generation iPhone game. From the big, finger-friendly buttons conveniently placed on opposite corners of the screen, to the simplistic level design, to the generic graphics.  * The simple level design gives the game a very low difficulty level. I understand the point of the game is to score points and not just to reach the bottom of the map, but I wish there were a few more levels where it would be a challenge to reach the landing pad.  * Although there are several dozen levels (80), the variety of them is lacking. Each level is essentially the same as the last; none of them seem more or less fun than any others.  * No backgrounds in any level. Every level has a simple color gradient for a background. How about at least a simple sky wallpaper?    The Ugly:    * The game has a horrible name. There is no way I am going to talk to my friends and be able to mention this game by name, which hurts word-of-mouth recommendations. It's as if the developers  chose this name because they wanted to come first alphabetically, and then later released '1...2...3... Kick It' when they realized that numbers precede letters in Steam's alphabetizing system.    Verdict:    Watch a few videos of the game online. Wou will have more fun watching other people play the game than doing it yourself.

Very quicly loses its appeal. Nothing stands out in terms of gameplay, sound, graphics or replayability. Gameplay is even fickle at times, it's tough to say what will cause you to lose the level or what you will 'bounce' off of. Played for as long as I did to try and unlock all the levels, but I had a really hard time trying to force myself to play. Not willing to go back to previous levels to get more in-game currency to unlock variations of the same mechanics copy and pasted across a wall of cubes. Not even sure if the game is 'beatable', I'll be placing this title in the 'abandonware' category of my library.
Garish colors, grainy looks, lowres everything, and it even does not feel like you are falling.   Stay away at all costs.
If you like licking men's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s then you will love this game because you are a ♥♥♥♥♥♥
HAHAHA DISREGARD THAT, I SUCK GRAVITY!
BASE Jumping: The Game. 80 levels, mostly involving you jumping off a building and falling near them for points. Has a peculiar sense of humour.

Only got this game mainly because of the competition, but its actually pretty fun. The basics is you use the wasd to controll your characters while hes falling and you do stuff during the fall to gain points before you get to the end and land...  The design is strange and the presentation sucks, but the core gameplay is actually fun and you unlock new 'abilites' during the way to keep the core game interesting. Add to that you can unlock any level you want from the level select screen you wont get bogged down on one level you cant get through. Gain rank in a level, 1-5 stars, gives you 'teeth' points and these points are used to unlock new levels. The concept works.  The resolution could have been better, but I recommend it while its on sale at 75% off and the competition level is the first one to the left you can unlock next to the introduction text boxes. The ach is pretty simple and you can also view it on Youtube if you serach the level 'Mash Face Against Mountain'.

This game is pretty quirky. It's unique and certainly very challenging but, for me at least, it wasn't interesting enough for me to want to finish the game. The challenge on most levels is just about memorising the layout and finding the path with the highest score. There are plenty of levels though.

If your the type of person who would jump off a cliff if someone asked you to, this might be the game for you.  The game is all about base jumping on a acid city replica of Boston, Massachusetts, some natural mountain landscapes and even places which look like they have been ripped out of the movie '5th element'.  The object is simple 'don't become a flattened pancake'. The other objective is to get a 5 star high score so you can earn 'teeth' the in-game currency (that's what we going to use when we run out of paper?) which you can spend to unlock more levels. Each level you complete you get treated to some funny news announcements or instructional videos. One video teaches you the do's and don'ts of accidental time travel, another video teaches you grandma's secret ingredient in her choc chip cookies being human remains and the list goes on. Most of these are either novel or groan out loud weakly executed attempts of humor.  There are a number of ways to build up your score. The main one is to kiss a building (get so close you can plant your smackers on it) and to hug them (free fall down at a constant close distance), but you can also do other things such as give a two fingered salute to red spectators (Mr Bean is Professional at that) and a thumbs up to blue ones, you can also graffiti tag certain buildings on your way down, smash into a bird, hit various glass colored plates for money, or perform the very tricky thread a needle move.  Most of the time you will struggle to do any of this as you will be too busy in a g spin of certain death since the controls are ridiculously hard to master. Hit a building and you become a human pinball against concrete flippers. I dare you to smoke a joint and try this with rift. You will be vomiting up your lungs as your characters nasal passage begins to smell the back of his brain thanks to the constant concrete jungle your treated to.  With all these things going on and it's unique game style you would think that this would be thumbs up material. It ISN'T. The game gets tedious and laborious fast. It gets too difficult too quickly, you might get 5 stars on two of the levels if your lucky. While it is possible to get 5 stars on the other levels, still you will soon discover that you will need to spend this life time, and your next reincarnated life time, or your next eternal life on a paradise earth, or your next life time being burnt alive forever and ever, but look on the bright side least you don't have to get five stars on this anymore.  The other reason it's thumbs down is because there is another version on Steam which is exactly the same, but contains more content with more 'polished' controls since it uses a different game engine. The other game is called 'AaAaAAAA!!! - for the awesome'. So if your interested 'Go! .... Go Jump off a cliff!.... What are you waiting for??? .... JUMP!!!!'
fast paced action and challenging game

If you feel bad about always wanting to jump off of buildings like me, then this game is for you. In this game you can jump off of buildings and touch other buildings to rack up points as you fall to impress all of your friends that coaxed you down from the top of uni last week.
I love this games style, mechanics and story. Definately recommend it!

3/10  In a nutshell: Fall and don’t touch stuff….  Pros: Easy to play.   Cons: It’s extremely repetitive. It’s hard to see someone playing this for hours on end.  Other thoughts: Save your money. Unless its dirt cheap.

I had a pretty fun time just falling c: This is really a game for completionists.. and people who love replaying thingss.. over and overrrr. Simple but effective gameplay and humourous style that doesn't take itself seriously at all. Some people will think it's lame and cliche, but that's point, really~ Good enough to recommend if you can get a copy cheaply. Not a bad game at all but one of those ones that feels almost like work too soon after you start playing.

It's a good game. Not great, but good. It hasn't aged terribly well and/or looks like a student's game, particularly with the models and random other images strewn throughout to try to distract you. There's a lot of replayability though, with leaderboards and really just trying to improve your own skills. It's not enough to keep me playing for that long, but it's a decent romp.

I bought this game a long time ago but never reviewed it. My problem with this game was that you couldnt look where you were supposed to go without speeding up. And controlling your speed was critical.  .....So the game is simple; jump off of a building, avoid obstacles, direct yourself though bonus areas for points, or just follow the fastest route.  .....Unfortunately, looking in a given direction moves you in that direction. So you have no control over your body, just your head. So if you look straight down, so you can see where you're going, you accelerate down. Faster and faster until you can't change direction fast enough to survive. Looking up or to the side slows you down, but then you can't see where you're going. .....On the other hand; while you can't control your body, it can kill you. For example, you are directed to skirt certain objects for bonus points, but if you got too close, your body would hit them and you died. The margin for error was tiny, and extremely frustrating.  .....I have this game listed under those games that should have been fun, but weren't.
All you do is jump of buildings. 2/10.
Just take the jump, fun game if played every now and than.

Personal Rating: 6/10 Genre: Daredevil Stunt Arcade Score Attack Plays like: Pilotwings (Skydive levels), very few games like it.  Very unique game about..well falling from great heights. Every level begins with the character jumping off a skyscraper and falling at high speed. You must hit score blocks and perform simple stunts to increase your score. Playing dangerously will reward you more points which is the main goal of the game. Nailing a perfect rating on each course will take many many hours. If you're looking for a very different type of game and love achieving high scores, this is the game for you.

Interesting, kinda fun, quite hard, and very weird.
One of the most fun games ever. Challenging, fast and addictive, it's the perfect 'one more time' game

An abstract simulation of falling in the future--sudden stop at the end is optional. AaAaAA!!! is a pleasant blend of absurd humor and breakneck action that will leave you disoriented and slightly sore. A more grounded argument is at  http://www.pixelsocks.com/2010/06/14/review-aaaaa/
A fun little game that will make Acrophobia sufferers have an anxiety attack. I think there's a new version out that I haven't tried, but this one is pretty good too.

It's worth it. The gameplay, the style, and the humor is extremely enjoyable. Inexpensive to boot. Totally recommended for anyone who loves a fun game that isn't too challanging, but can offer it at times.

Having played through most of this game, I can safely say that I didn't enjoy a single minute of it.  The idea of base jumping through futuristic, laser-skyway cities has some definite appeal, but when it amounts to simply traversing around elongated blocks at a steady pace with some retro acid-trip inspired background trying to compete for eye focus, the product leaves you wanting.  The humor is 'LOL so randum XD' and the devs shamelessly plugged themselves into a number of levels. The game is basically built around high scores, in the same vein as classic arcade games. But when the leaderboards are dominated by hackers (a million points in the tutorial level? Please) with no moderation in sight, that takes out the possibility of an ePeen simulator.  One positive about this game is the level design. Some of the courses are really cunning, and I like game designers that twist and bend the rules of their own game to make a variety of new experiences.
A perfect example of mindless and innocent fun. A silly concept, but oddly addicting at the same time.
I LIKE THIS GAME SO MUCH I HAVE BOUGHT IT A TOTAL OF SIX TIMES NOW.
Simple, stupid arcady game not to be taken seriously. But it's fun to virtually flip people off.
Hey, just go for AaAaAA!! - For the Awesome, it has all of the levels from this game I believe, so unless you are just interested in half measures, this one probably isn't worth it.
SOOOO ADDICTING! Lots of levels, and random bits!
If you want this get, get the newer game. It is the same game just updated with better graphics and a lot more content.

If you've ever wanted to base jump off a huge building than this again for you. It puts creativity to falling from the sky. The graphics alright. The music is really unique. It just has a charm that keeps you coming back for more. While falling you can give gestures to onlooking fans or give the bird to onlooking protesters. You can spray paint buildings on your way down. It's a very enjoyable game to relax to. The levels are very unique in style. There is much humor in this game and if you enjoy these type games then you won't regret buying it. A must-have for any wannabe skydiver!

It's about time I summarize this one. Had it for awhile now. Bought it a couple years back. A friend had gotten it first, and I tried it out.  It's pretty great if you're under the influence of anything. Also good at over stimulating yourself. The achievements aren't really tough, but take real long to get.  Good for a distraction, I liked the soundtrack, as well as the bogus jokes.  For it's price it's got a lot of replay time.  It's a stellar cliff-jumping experience, if you're not into the real thing.
Do you like falling? Do you like falling to cool music? Do you like giving the finger to people on the way down? Buy the game, support indie developers.
I rather watch somebody ♥♥♥♥ for an hour than play this for 10 minutes.

It doesn't look all that exciting, but it really is a lot of fun. The flavor news casts and videos add alot to the experience. Seemingly unhelpful tips like 'Look up when you're falling up' turn out to be good advice.
A fun little game, like base jumping in cyberspace.  If you enjoy speed and precise controls, you'll have a ball. I thought it wore thin over the long haul though.
I heartily reccomend this, for it is quite good and also cheap. Buy it, or do not, for it is of no consequence to I.

Achievement progress at time of writing: 5/7 (71%)  This is more like a puzzle game, with stages in which you need to base jump, get close to structures, perform actions, and land within a target. It's pretty simple mechanically, though it wasn't very engaging. There is almost zero story, just something about it being the new sport of the future.  What you see in the trailer is pretty much the game. I personally did not enjoy it all that much.

It has an awesome name. What more do you need?  This is a game for people who are obsessed with maximizing their score and topping the leaderboards, or at least topping yourself. The game is entirely about navigating an artistic representation of an impossible city as you jump from the tallest building and weave your way through the concrete maze to land safely at the bottom. On your way down, you'll collect bonuses for staying close to buildings as they whizz by and smashing through targets. That's about it. As you unlock more levels, the challenges get tougher, but this is a pretty fun distraction if you've got a few minutes to spare.
Defently worth playing if you enjoy trying to do as best as you can. Random commentary, music and unlockables, let alone so many levels and things to go back and try, really do make this game good.

I did this for one of the steam gifts, but honestly, this is one of the better indie games I own on Steam. Base jump, break through glass, flip off onlookers, and 'kiss' walls to a high score. It's a ♥♥♥♥ ton of fun.
This is weird, trippy and awesome. Kiss the buildings and hug the walls. Flick the fingers at the moaners. This is the shiz.

This is the greatest game I've played since Super Mario Bros. 2. It features a foul-mouthed degenerate who enjoys jumping off buildings and landing on the hard pavement below.   The game features some of the best voice-acting I've heard in a video game, but what really stands boner out is the games ability to give you a massive gamenema.   I enjoyed this game because it is a good suicide emulator for people who like to jump off high places and flip off walls.   Game gets a 8/10 for having large amounts of falling and that's about all. Also, there is a level where you have to catch falling babies before they hit the pavement, but it's impossible because they have rockets attached to them pointing to the ground below.  I got kicked in the groin alot by the big dinosaurs and uniformed japanese officers.   This game has everything, even a game inside it, it's a game within' a game, kinda like Pokemon Puzzle League.   To quote a great man 'Game is good game'  Get it.
It's more fun than I expected.
Got this for the steam treasure hunt, spent way too many hours playing it since then. Great game!
Fun game. Plays well on a laptop with intel graphics.
Play it. You won't regret it. Trust me.
Fun and educational. A+++ would fall again.
A visually stunning game with perfect sound effects to match the gameplay and a great soundtrack. If you love flying or gliding in games, you will love the feel of this game.

I know this Dejobaan game came before Drunken Robot Pornography, but I played DRP first, and amazingly, that game was actually easy compared to this one. Despite the fact that this game is frustrating as hell, it is still amazing. Graphically, right from the first spit second of the menu screen, this game is a thrill to play. Unlike DRP, this game says exactly what it entails, and that is the sound you'd be making if you were the protagonist in this game. You jump off a building, you scale buildings for points, you meet score quotas to earn stars which, in turn, earn you teeth which you use to unlock new levels. Again, like DRP, Dejobaan proves that you don't have to be complicated to be an amazing game. Just pair stunning visuals with great music and COUNTLESS levels. I've been playing this for a hours and i still haven't unlocked them all. And for a game where all you do is fall, that's pretty damn good.

A basejumping game with a style similar to the old school skateboarding games. (This game makes me think of the old Playstation title Grind Session.) The gameplay couldn't be simpler. W,A,S,D for movement and space to deploy your parachute. Try to get as close to the buildings as possible without actually crashing into them, and try to collect as many points as you can on the way down. What's not to like?
Great indie game with a good sense of humour and original gameplay mechanics. Great indie developer.

A nice game to buy when it's on sale. Plenty of content, but I got stuck after a few levels and couldn't progress any further because I couldn't get enough teeth. Check out my full review here:   http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PvG8mVlxCpQ

Dream Entry 235  It came back. I thought I was rid of it but it dragged me back like some horror movie monster. Once again I was falling. I was hugging and kissing buildings. I was rude to random people I didn't even know. Worst yet, I think I killed a bird. That feeling of dread when your body is plunging towards the earth, that rush of pulling the rip cord and letting your feet touch the ground. I hate it. It is too loud, too disjointed, just too much. Why where there people there watching me fall like it was some kind of spectator sport? If there is a merciful God out there, he will end these nightmares of sky and wind. He will stop torturing me with the pain of the bright lights and sounds. He will end the pointing and laughing of these perverse strangers and not make me the death of that poor bird. But I know he won't. That sick ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=22DgMLjEM0g  If you rolled the skydiving game from Pilotwings in LSD and sent it hurtling into the future, you’d surely end up with something similar to A Reckless Disregard for Gravity. The game is set in a psychedelic, alternate-reality version of Boston, Massachusetts in which buildings are nonsensically scattered throughout 3D space. This convoluted landscape provides the perfect playground for base jumpers with a reckless… you know. You play as one such base jumper from a first person perspective. Each level sees you taking a leap of faith from the tallest building, navigating your way through an architectural maze, then gracefully landing on a platform at then end. On your way down you rack up points by maneuvering dangerously close to obstacles and smashing through glass panels. As you progress you’ll unlock other abilities such as flipping off protesters and giving your fans a thumbs up. Snaking your way through a deadly obstacle course while chaining together the appropriate gestures is incredibly satisfying. It takes some time to get used to the controls, but the payoff is worth it. I would have liked to have seen joystick support, and the menu system could use some serious work, but otherwise A Reckless Disregard for Gravity is a clever game with a fun sense of humor that will leave you itching for one more jump.
An odd game that is equal parts adrenaline and frustration. It's a nice little break from the ordinary, but it's not something I can play for hours and hours.
The jumps you make are not about science, they are about a reckless disregard for gravity. WOOOOOOOOOOWEEAAAAAYEAHAHAAAAAA.

Funny, off-beat, slightly weird, and definitely insane, AaAaAA!!! is worth every penny just for Nebin the radio announcer alone. The levels are fun, twitchy, demanding, and always something different. With titles like: 'Crandall Tower now with Extra Pea Soup' and 'The Illuminati are just People with Lamps' the game is a treasure trove of non-sequiteurs that is perfect for 3am gaming when the insomnia is making the hallucinations kick in.
Exactly what it looks like. Do you find yourself finding the tallest mountains and buildings in games in order to fling yourself off them? Well, this is that game and nothing else. Bro.
This game is pretty fun in small doses, I wouldn't pay 10 bucks for it though.
Oh, now I know the proper name - AaAaAA!. The game is totally awesome, and I recomend that one to you. Just try it.
Gravity sucks, this game fixes that.
This is the best game about intentionally breaking every bone in your body ever made.

There...are no words to describe the level of insanity this game operates on. It's as if the insanity from one dimension overflowed into another dimension which was full of highly illegal substances, and those two dimensions said 'screw it' and jumped off a building. This isn't a game, it's an experience.   I'm going to have a lie down.

Falling at high speed through psychedelic landscapes, constantly trying to balance risk vs reward as you scrape past buildings certainly has its thrills even if they are short lived. Also in the game.
I think the devs were completely stoned. However, that's not a bad thing - they designed an interesting, if trippy game.

'Vertigo is anguish to the extent that I am afraid not of falling over the precipice, but of throwing myself over,' Sartre said in Being and Nothingness. When I consider the possibility of me playing this game, I consider one of the possible possibilities not determined by a foreign cause, but by my own being instead. As someone who avoids death would avoid a precipice, I avoid anguish by nihiliating the possibility of me deciding to play this game anymore.   AaAaAAvoid this game!!!

While full immersion, force-feedback enabled first-person base jumping games are still a ways out of the reach of current technology, Reckless Disregard makes me hopeful for the future. In the meantime, I will utilize my high suspension of disbelief stat and create my own immersion while plummeting to my death in this game.  Good times!

Fun game for what it is. Its like a game where you jump off a building trying to either pass through point circles or 'touch' other buildings while falling. A bit tricky to get a good score. Played the heck out of it during the Portal 2 Arg. Then never touched it again.

AaAaAA!!! - A Reckless Disregard for Gravity is an average game built on a fairly unique concept of doing tricks while falling off fantasy suspended structures. While the game does feature a wide variety of playmaps and modes, and the unlocking and teeth currency system are welcome, the game has some pretty noticeable flaws. First and foremost is the lack of controller support, which given the twitch nature of the gameplay seems like a must. Secondly, the game does not feature any interesting music and the sound effects particularly for the parachute are quite poor. I had fun with this title for a few minutes, but the tedium grows as these flaws repeat over each game session. I would recommend this game only to action fans who want a novel concept but caution others to stay away.

A goofy game where you base jump through hoops while trying to flick people off. Punk style sense of humor and strange array of difficulty distrobution in the levels make this game interesting and fun. I beat most of them pretty quickly though.

Fairly addicting game if you are into those arcade-like games that have intricate scoring systems. It's a B.A.S.E. jumping that encourages hugging buildings as closely as possible without running into them. With the distinct simplistic art style it has managed to create an image for itself. Recommended.

I dislike Dejobaan games, very much. They feel cheap and ill-maintained, as well as little consideration to practical functionality.  On the other hand, that can all be overlooked with this one. Sure, the menu system is terrible, sure it takes too much effort to organize - but what a fun little game!  The objective is basically to hug buildings, survive and land well; in that order. Hugging buildings is very fun - it can get tricky at times but that's the challenge really. The levels are a little short and I haven't unlocked the bigger, harder (?) ones - but for now i'm satisfied.  Surviving is however easy to make it for yourself; those high points only come from kissing/hugging buildings (their terminology, I promise you). It takes some practice and a few quick-thinking moments but you can rack up those numbers. There's even 'bonus' things to smash. Lastly is landing safely; relatively easy to get it into the landing area.  In summary - a great little mini-game, lazy developers.
As punk as a Jeff Minter game. Worth playing for the experience. ♥♥♥♥ the actual game, cos while it has its moments, that ain't why you're here.
Crazy and deserving of a lot of attention. Excellent vertical First Person strangeness!
Great game, loads of levels, hours of fun!

Awesome game. Oh and there's a pretty awesome addictive falling game in there as well.
As long as you can handle a little vertigo, you won't regret this game. Indie, stylish, quirky, fun. The only thing it's missing is multiplayer.
This game could not be any more indie unless the developer cut himself in half. Seriously though the game isn’t half bad and if getting gold medals gets your jimmies rusled then go all for it.

A nice experimental game style. You are a base jumping freak, in a totally freaky world. Try to fly through gates, spray buildings and high-five your fans.  I like the absolutely messed up ideas. There are different parts of the game which are unbelievably crazy. Undescribable.  6 out of 10*

Game aims to recapture extreme skydiving. It fails. Game gets the silly idea that skydiving would be more interesting with floating buildings... it just makes the game seem less immersive. The graphics heavily distract from the game, and don't add to it at all. They tried too hard to look hip, anot not enough time trying to be good. Game would have been significantly better if instead of going through the tricky level design, if they had just grabbed some 3d data of the world and made base jumping in famous locations.   I can see their reason for their 'floating cities' (to make their base jumping take longer) but if they're going to try that, they should at least make their floating cities look like floating cities above distant ground and not shipping containers being thrown at you by a wall of neon lava.  I'm not normally one to complain about graphics (look at my other reviews if you don't believe me) but the graphics and level layout in this make the game horrible.
An interesting indy game that will keep you playing for hours. The gameplay is simple, but challenging, and keeps you shooting for the highest score. A great indie game to try out and master.

This game is more fun than it should be. The game mechanic is unlike almost anything out there, the levels are similar to each other but with enough differences to keep it interesting, it offers high score challenges to accomodate any level of player and the humor and 'story' of the game are all enjoyable. Even the progress system as you choose levels and unlocks is fun and how often do you ever hear that about a game.

From the most disinterested newcaster, to the unusual guides to making cookies, AaAaAA!!! is a game that will pull you along for the fall (literally). You are a base jumper in a floating city the seems to have a '♥♥♥♥ the government!' attitude, and you jump off buildings, falling close to other buildings to gain points. If this doesn't seem interesting to you then you need help.  You can graffiti buildings, flip off spectators, smash into birds, break through scoring glass, fly so close to rugged mountains that you'll lose your belly and ♥♥♥♥ yourself laughing at some of the in-game antics.  Buy this game, you'll never regret it.

There isn't anything in this game to hold your attention for an acceptable amount of time. It's fun for a brief few moments, but you'll just be doing the same thing over and over again. It's one of those games which doesn't really grasp the concept that fun isn't enough to support an entire game. Its entire draw is that the core gameplay is fun, but everything else is utterly lacking. There's no story and nothing to hope for as you progress through the game. You won't find yourself wondering if new game mechanics will be added. You won't find yourself wondering if a new upgrade will change how you play the game. You start the game, and then you have the option to keep playing forever. If you're a REALLY big fan of the engine and place no value in your time, then you might get more enjoyment out of this game than me. But it's 10 dollars! Don't spend that much money on a game like this! I can personally recommend a dozen flash games that will give you a more rewarding experience. Especially considering that they released a better version of this game which COSTS THE SAME AMOUNT!!  They're trying to fleece you. That's the best way to describe this. You're given a little bit of fun at ten times the price it should be. The product that you're given isn't meant to stand the test of time at all. It's only meant to be good enough to keep you from complaining.
Freefalling through point boards and hugging the sides of buildings is pretty damn fun. The real winner though is the game's sense of humor.
this ♥♥♥♥ing game makes me ♥♥♥♥ing angry but satisfied at the same time!!! 10/10!!!

Title:  AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome  Genre:  Action, Indie, Sports  Developer:  Dejobaan Games, LLC   Publisher:  Dejobaan Games, LLC   Release Date:  3 Sep, 2009  Lets avoid those broken bones by not falling face first into a building, and remembering you have a parachute on your back.   Gameplay
sometimes i like to pretend im a astronaut who was spaced, and i wonder what my last thoughts would be as i burn up on re-entry.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rRUwiwA51r0  Above is my video impressions of the game  AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome is an interesting game with some pretty simple mechanics. It's all about jumping off of buildings and accumulating as much points as possible. The game features a ton of levels and features to unlock, with some pretty eye catching aesthetics.  The game is simple and that is both it's strength and weakness. It's easy to jump into and will grab player's attention very quickly, but because of it's extremely simple design, it could possibly lose the player's interest just as fast. It's really upto you to decide whether or not the game is worth your money.  Pros: - Good looking - Easy to understand mechanics - Can be thrilling at times  Cons: - Overly simple - Might not hold the attention of some players

Such a fun game and a great edition to anyones libary. This game has so many good aspects and an amazing sense of humour, for example you can swear at the people that dislike you and give your fans a thumbs up!

This Game is absolutly amazing, it totally understands what it is trying to do and does it perfectly. The only question is do you understand what it is trying to do?  If you are wondering to yourself 'wait in these clips it seems like you could just go on the outside of these courses' the anwser is yes, yes you can. And have absolutly nothing in your way so you can master the movement without getting frustrated. Getting frustrated? THE GAME HAS A SOLUTION TO IT!!!!! It will go through breathing exersices with you to calm you down. Getting the movement down to a useable level is really easilly but mastering it is really hard.   I absolutly love this game from start to just leaving it in your library for every-once-in-awhile play.

This game is awesome. If you enjoy the concept, you're going to have a blast. If you don't, well, there's not a ton of variety in this game. It's a skydiving simulator set in a Tron world on acid by way of an infant subversive through and through. The controls are just tight enough to make it work and it gets pretty intense down the road.  The Oculus Rift support doesn't hurt, either. This'll be the first game I load up when mine finally arrives. Because I love puking, apparently.

I've booked quite a few hours playing this game over the last year. Great Game where you fall from the top of a building weaving between buildings, kissing and hugging them. you even get to flip people off to score points...lol. Tons of levels and replayability. Graphics are simple but work fine for the game and while I do not have own one it supports Occulus Rift....seriously sweet.  Dejobaan Games is my favorite Indy developer.

While this game is a blast overall, it's even a greater experience in VR with its excellent Oculus Rift support since the days of the DK1, later adapted for the DK2 in full and updated regularly. I've actually gone as far as launching this game in VR during my work breaks. It's one of the best games to have a VR beginner try, as the feeling of falling is not only comfortable, but oddly relaxing and somewhat addicting over time.  A great, challenging concept overall. Excellent sense of humor. Driving sound tracks. Prime time VR support. Much safer than actually jumping off buildings in a wingsuit.

AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! ....For the Awesome, the Anti-Platformer!! In this game you will do all in your power to AVOID landing on them, as you leave every platform far behind!  I nearly made a mistake with this game (beyond thinking the dreadful title actually said something about the game, that is): I read the reviews. Then I read the awards it's won. Then I considered the type of games I enjoy most: pinball, Puddle, FOTONICA. Flowing, limited control type games. Actually, the decision was easier with more information. And I made the correct one.  WHAT a game! While some call it 'boring and repetitive' how can the possibilites of every building, tower, mountain in the UNIVERSE possibly be boring! People accustomed to absolute control, who have paid large sums to get games to perform in very precise ways, might not understand how gravity, and a body falling at very high speeds, are forces beyond simple control. They should play The Collider, a fine game with a similar basis. In THIS game you are being pulled by the force of an entire PLANET! Control must be earned, and learned....  Basically, after completing some ridulously simple tutorials you are given a building to leap from. On the way down you gain points by coming close to objects, coming VERY close to objects, hitting score-coded, colored glass plates, and not smashing to boney, bloody bits. By succeeding, and obtaining enough points, you will reach awards of 1 to 5 stars. Each star pays off in 'teeth', the currency used to unlock new levels, of which there are more than 80. Teeth can also be used to buy things like the 'flip-it' glove, to either give a thumbs-up to fans, or the opposite to haters. Yes, of course, granting additional points.   Once you have fallen as far as you feel is safe, a player opens their 'fins' in order to glide safely to a smooth landing, possibly on a high-scoring smaller target. All movement is performed by mouse and the ubiquitous WASD keys (or controller.) But one must keep in mind that despite the availability of directional keys, a falling/floating body will ultimately move forward, to the exclusion of most other directions or intentions. One quickly learns the power of 'spiraling'.  You may also unlock tongue-in-cheek 'relaxing meditations' (for significantly lower prices,) or (so far) a cookie recipe from the strangest old, pseudo-cannibal lady ever. The purpose of spending teeth is not just new levels and objects, but access to yet more, since you must unlock an adjacent level before opening a new one on a tall, turning 'level drum'. Prices increase with progression, and only hints are given as to what will be found once a choice is made.  There are also many bits of BASE jumping trivia, at no cost, basically to fill out he wall. A!FtA (for lack of better) does have achievements, but mostly for putting in the time, and only ten of them. Not a lot can be done to actively pursue them, other than sitting in a dark room, slowly wasting away. You know, the usual.  IF this is your game, it is VERY much your game. A marvelous, funny AND fun game. So much fun as to not provoke the rage tendancies that will cause me to 'delete local content' almost immediately. No two jumps are likely to be even remotely similar, since the distances fallen can be great. For me, it's almost as much fun to die as to win. Almost...  (Like many Steam games, offline game time is ignored.) 4tdc

I might just be terrible, but I don't find this game any entertaining at all. Sure, there's a bunch of content, it's challenging and scales well as you go through it, but I never really found it too entertaining. Not a big fan of how it looks, or the humor they're going for, or the way the menu works and looks.

Recently snagged this in a Bundle and AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! For The Awesome is stellar. A Puzzle game about a base jumping person. Or is it an adventure game. Or one of those arty farty indie 'life story' games about a suicidal person falling to their death and realising how thrilling life can really be when you do something spontanious. Cheered by the thrill of falling, and the daring of spraypaints and high fives from observers.   No idea.  What I do know is this game is a strange kind of fun. The idea is simple enough - fall from a great height and collect as many points as you can before you hit the bottom. Be daring and 'kiss' the lips of buildings, spray paint your logo wherever you can, wave to your fans are you plummett and make that soft landing. The more style you put into each trip to the bottom equals more money; more money equals more goodies and unlocks. Simples.  There's a strange sort of anti-oppression narrative tacked in there too, for those who seek reason for madness. However, it's a lot more fun to just pick up and play this game in small bursts. Long play throughs will probably lead to burn out. No joke.  That's not to say that this game doesn't have it's frustrating moments, but that's more to do with the game's levels and ramping difficulty rather than any ill-fated design decision or game breaking bug.   So, if you're looking for a 'pick up and play' kind of game that can fill a 10-20 minute gap here and there then I do believe 'AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome' could be the game you're looking for. It often goes cheap in the various Steam Sales too, so there's always that if you're really unsure about picking it up.
Too much repetitive. May be a good experience for those who like flying and speed, though.  3/10

Welcome to the first ever falling simulator that ive ever seen. I wouldnt recommend this game to anyone whos looking for a real good time but others may have a different opinion. For what you pay this game is very basic allowing you simply to fall while avoiding obsticles with the more risk you take earning you more points. You start with only a handful of maps to choose from but you have to earn points to spend unlocking other maps. This leads to alot of repetition just to allow yourself access to more repetition. The cost is made up for by the number of maps you can unlock as the game progresses but I dont find that to be all that worth it.

This game is a gravity simulation. You jump off buildings and try to avoid getting killed by other buildings. You need to work your way through the maze of buildings (while getting as close to them as you can for points). Then you must land. Pretty fun. Has lots of obsticles but it gets boring after a while. You need great reaction time for this game. I would give it a 68/100.

This game is absurd, let's start with that. The motivational speeches, the therapy, the hints ... all weird. But entertaining.  The game itself, the gameplay that is, is amusing and fun. But in short bursts. I enjoy booting this game for 15 minutes or so at a time, that way it doesn't start to bore me. It's still quite unique. :)  I recommend it when it's pretty cheap, or if you're able to get it from an indie bundle somewhere for nearly no money at all.

It takes a short while to get used to but this score-attack game absolutely clicked with me. The game really comes into its own once you have got competent at all the basics and played most of the basic mode levels then charge in to the 'awesome' mode which is much faster and honestly even more fun. Just like in real life, hugs and kisses are very moreish, and in the week I've been playing it I keep wanting to come back to it for about an hour at a time. Plus I keep getting amusing chat reactions to 'Gagaman is currently playing AaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!!' which is a bonus.
Ridiculously entertaining. Not deep, just a lot of fun and a good stress reliever.
Ridiculously entertaining. Not deep, just a lot of fun and a good stress reliever.

Really awesome and fun game where the player freefalls through an obstacle course and attempts to rack up as high a score as possible. Gain points by getting close to buildings, gesturing at spectators, and various other stunts. The highest scoring paths are usually the most risky, so be careful not to crash and die :) This is one of those concepts that is easy to learn, but difficult to master. There are endless hours of fun, trying to get high scores on over 100 maps. Graphics are simple but effective, and the music adds to the intensity. The low purchase price is great value for money.

A simple indie game about falling near things. I was bored by the concept very quickly, but YMMV. They made the menus fun and interesting, so it has a bit of style but (to me) no substance. I'm betting I got this as a title in a Humble Bundle - not sure anymore.

Gameplay: Controls feel awfully inaccurate, pretty bad for a game that is all about precision and speed. You fall down a couple hundrets predesigned levels in first person view and touch the walls or fall thru rings/squares for extra points. Nothing ever changes. Bored me real quick. Graphics: Ok for a small indie titly nothing really great tho.

Buy this if you think Microsoft Excel is too exciting for you.  Seriously, very sorry to say, but I think it's an absolutely horrendous game. Zero excitement. Zero. Bad graphics (worse than many cell phones today). Zero thrill. Insanely boring.   Gameplay goes like this:  -> you walk (more like slowly inching your way) off a 'building'  -> you 'fall' (more like slowly drift) towards something supposed to be downwards  -> you steer clear of stuff (big blocks/pixels) on your way down, and try to hit various targets on the way down etc.  -> you deploy your 'chute' (which is stated to be a helicopter-thingy?) and land  -> repeat ad naseum.  No render of a ground or imminent dangers. Just blocks and stuff magically hovering in mid-air on your way down. No resemblance to an actual base-jump, or parachute-jump for that matter, whatsoever. You can unlock different places to 'jump'.   Why not make it go fast, like a real jump? Why not add the whooshing sound of air, or add the instability from the air resistance that rushing towards the ground gives you? Why no content or graphics? Why doesn't anything look like real buildings, or real persons, or anything real? I've tried countless games, in a broad spectre of genres, all the way from the Sinclair ZX and Commodore in the 80s, but this really burns itself on the retina and memory as a really, really bad gaming experience.  I will, however, not tell you how this game is with Oculus Rift, because I haven't tried it. Maybe it's better? Could be. Seriously, it could be. Maybe the VR-goggles can transform crap to tolerable.  Personally, I doubt it. But hey, each to his own.
YeeeEEEEEEeeeessSSSS! Can't wait to play this with the Oculus Rift....   The damn thing ALREADY has support for it....

AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awful is what this game should have been called.

As I'm typing this review, I literally just realized that the 'A's' on the title aren't completely at random, they have a pattern. And that's pretty awesome. You know what else is awesome? This game.   'AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome' is a Base Jumping Simulator developed by Dejobaan Games and Owlchemy Labs, and it has an awesome sense of humor. You may have noticed how much I've used the word 'awesome' outside of the title. That's because it is the best word to describe this game. It's not beautiful, it's not revolutionary, it's not unforgettable, it's just awesome. You know the 'Awesome' smiley face that you see on the internet every once in a while? Yeah, that kind of awesome. But exactly why is this game awesome? Let's take a closer look.   First of all, this game has no story. At all. There is no main character; the game is in first-person so it looks like the person jumping is you! Why are you jumping? I don't know, because it's awesome, maybe? Is there some kind of hidden lore that I'm missing? Probably not, and if there is, it's VERY well hidden.   The presentation of this game is decent. There are no real characters in this game, meaning that there are no 3D models of any creature. So what we can judge is the buildings and structures that you'll be falling dangerously close to (or on to). The great majority of the shapes that you will see in this game are rather basic. Buildings are rectangles; there's some rings here and there; most platforms are squares; etc. Really, the most complex-looking model that you're going to see in this game are mountains. The textures are not impressive or super-detailed, either. The Heads-Up Display isn't anything spectacular or admiring to look at. And actually, it's OK for this game in particular to not look like it was made by Square Enix. Because you're constantly falling non-stop, you will never have time to take an in-depth look at all the objects in the levels. Honestly, it's better that way, because it won't distract you from trying not to fall to your doom. So in short, this game looks simplistic; it looks as good as it needs to look.   OK, here's the important one: the gameplay. In 'Aaaaa! for the Awesome' (that's the short way to say it), the goal is to jump off the building at which the levels starts you on and reach the bottom while making as many points as possible. In order to gain points, you must 'fly near stuff' as the game says, which will earn you 'Hugs' and 'Kisses.' Early on in the game, you will gain the ability to thumbs-up your fans, flip-off angry mobs, and spray municipal buildings with graffiti. A lot of levels also have breakable score plates and special plates that may or may not help you. The controls only consist of 4 keys on the keyboard and the mouse, and it does support a gamepad. But due to the game's simple controls, I don't find a gamepad necessary; the mouse and keyboard work just fine. Whenever you complete a level, you will gain a certain amount of Teeth and Kneecaps based on your score, and you can use these to unlock other levels. Now that I explained the gameplay, how enjoyable was it? Well, the game is fun. The slight feeling of vertigo that you get from falling thousands of meters in the air is pretty exciting. Despite how dangerous and realistically stupid of an idea it might be, you will always want to 'fly near stuff' as much as possible to ensure that you get the highest score, and for those who are competitive, you will probably try one level several times until you see 5 / 5 stars with a huge score sitting beside it. As you progress, the levels will become increasingly more challenging, though I don't believe the game ever got to a point where I just wanted to rip my hair off. But the game is not perfect, however. It is simple and easy-to-learn, but I personally didn't find 'Aaaaa! for the Awesome' to be noticeably addicting. If you want to beat the game in one sitting, you can probably do it in 3 - 4 hours, but it will start feeling repetitive and tedious after about an hour of playing. It's also worth noting that the game will not tell you your score until you finish or fail the level. But probably the biggest problem with this game is the lack of a level editor (at least there isn't one as far as I'm aware). The game offers 81 levels, and that's... sufficient, but I feel like this game could benefit SO much from User-Generated Content! I don't know if the developers are still willing to work with this game, but if they ever come back to it, please add a level editor. But as it stands, 'Aaaaa! for the Awesome' can be a fun game if played in short bursts, but I wouldn't advice binge playing it.   I guess let's talk about sound design for a bit. The game offers a techno-rock soundtrack that fits the general mood and style of the game, but it's not something that I may have a MIGHTY NEED to put on my MP3 player. There are actually a few pieces of voice acting in the game; the two you will hear the most is a man and a woman telling you how many Hugs and Kisses you have. There's also some videos narrated by the developers, and these videos will either be tutorials or talking about random things because yes. Oh, and let's not forget about Kevin... with the news. As far as sound effects go, I think they're mostly stock sounds of angry mobs, cheering, and hitting things. I do think they could have done a better job with those sound effects, particularly when you fall and break every bone in your body. The game tells you that you just broke everything, but it doesn't sound like it.   So all in all, what do I think about 'Aaaaa! for the Awesome?' It's definitely a fun game that does everything that it does good enough, but it's nothing mind-blowing. It knows what it wants to be, and tries to be nothing more. If you like awesome stuff, you'll like this game. And with the added support for Virtual Reality, it makes the game even better for those who own a VR device, though unfortunately that number isn't too high. Mind you, I'm a cheap booger, so I got this game from I believe a Humble Indie Bundle because I wouldn't pay $10 for it. But if you think this game is perfect for you (and specially if you own a VR device), go for it.

The greatest Arcade-style Sci-Fi Alternate History Base Jumping simulator since AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! - A Reckless Disregard for Gravity.  This may be due to the fact it contains all content from AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! A Reckless Disregard for Gravity, in addition to new 'Awesome' levels.  The 'Awesome' levels are legitimately Awesome. Just in case you were wondering.

This game is all about speed. If you've played the prequel, AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! a Reckless Disregard for Gravity, then you'll know what to expect. However, be warned, now you fall two times faster!  The original 83 levels are redone with brand new graphics and even more insane speeds. You will shout, you will scream, and you will curse as you die countless times, trying to get through the freaking level. Along with the original game's levels, there are more than 40 additional levels with brand new environments, making the world seem more realistic. The graphics are beautiful, the replayablility is insane, the gameplay is awesome, and the sound is fitting. However, there are a few low-res textures and hickups, so points must be taken for that.  Catagory Scores...  Graphics: A- Gameplay: A Sound: B+ Value: A+  Verdict: 'A' This is a must play...

Absolutely bursting with character. I wasn't sure whether I would enjoy this or not, but then I jumped off a building, and unlike in real life, where the end result is an unfortunate mess and a prime spot in the local obituary (or if you made a loud noise, the local paper front page), I found the whole experience to be absolutely thrilling.  It's a lovely example of a unique concept polished well, and given its own crazy personality to compliment the whole thing. Perfect little time waster, with some quite complex manouvres required for perfection, lending itself both to beginner building jumpers, and expert exo-base jumpers alike.  Really, there isn't quite a game like it, it's good.

Let's pretend for a moment that you want to make a video game. Let's also pretend that you don't have any 3d modeling or artistic ability whatsoever. How do you resolve a conundrum like that? Simple: abstract art!  This is the approach that the developers of AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome took when developing their base jumping simulator. There's a certain edge to the game, certainly, and it's got some style, but I just can't get over the fact that it'd be a lot more fun if the buildings I was flying past at high speeds looked like actual buildings.  Also, the buildings float, because this is the future. And because this is the future, base jumping is obviously now the way that you're going to take down the evil authoritarian government that somehow took over. Presumably you're angry because of the flying buildings...who knows?  Still, it's fun for a bit as a sort of combination racing/puzzle game.

This is a very fun game, fast paced and designed with lots of different elements to keep things interesting. It's a great distraction because it is a good challenge, and it seems that there are hundreds of levels and since no two jumps are the same on any level, it is vast as well.
Great game, but the graphics settings are too simple. I am forced to play a pulled out 4:3 image on a 16:9 screen (Linux).
fun and funny, wish i had an oculus, does a good job of portraying speed and tension.

AaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAAwesome! I've been waiting for a sale on this game, as I didn't know much about it. Now that I have purchased it, I can say this is just great! A Hidden gem of a game.  Now, if only I had an AAAAAAaaaaaCulous rift...  Will be getting for AAAAaaaaaAaaaAndroid aswell!

AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome played for 2 hours first impressions.  AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome is actually 2 games in one. The original game which is all the 'A's and the sequal which is called Awesome. It's a shame really as I was hoping to do a really crappy pun about the noise you will make when playing it. Actually it turns out that pun is pretty accurate as you will be saying both playing it :)  Before I start talking about this game I just want to let you guys know that I am not really the best person to talk about sports games. I don't really like sports and I tend to find the games equally as tedious. However there have been a couple of exceptions over the years and this is thankfully one of them. I think I've realised what it is now. The last sports game I really enjoyed was Mario Golf. I find Golf a bit of a mind blowing game, the only enjoyable thing I can think of is that its a nice walk on a pleasant day, but to watch it on tv is something I've never been able to understand, but like this game mario golf adds a lot of fun nice extras and it provides enough of a distraction. A for the A is similar. While you are jumping to possibly your death there are many things you can do. Your character will thumbs up any fans watching and make naughty gestures to those who protest, you get additional points for being a wreckless moron with a death wish by scraping your chin against buildings as you fall and you can spray graffiti too. Wait how does that even work? Never mind. You can also slam through glass plates for extra points. At the end you deploy your parachute and try to land in a small circle for bonus points which is a lot harder than it sounds as the parachute controlls terribly. Then you are graded, usually very poorly.  Holy crap is it hard though! You will find many hours of gameplay in this if its the kind of thing that you enjoy. I'm sure if you search youtube you will see people raging about it. You need to gain a high grade in order to gain teeth which is the in game currency to unlock the next level. However you only get teeth for gaining a better rank so there is a lot of grind. I have heard people complain that it is repetitive but it's a sporty game, of course its repetitive.   This game has a great sense of humour too, it is full of comedic parts and although a lot of it didn't work for me it's nice to see them there.  So after this positive review why am I not recommending it? Well...I feel bad for not doing so but the trouble is when I think about my friend circle, I can't think of anyone who would like it. It's something that I feel you should take a look at but it would require a lot of dedication to keep playing through it. The difficulty is incredibly high, and just because its hard doesn't make it negative is a rule I live by, but this is almost trapformer hard, I can see people getting really angry at it. It is kinda funny but it's a bit samey and the parachute controls will really wind you up. I understand why they made that part difficult but if you are falling for 4 5 maybe 6 minutes and you miss the circle by a pixel then you will be tearing your hair out.  I think this might be the sort of thing that works better on the tablet and indeed there is a tablet version, this seems to be the sort of thing you try and master slowly over several months while you are multitasking in the bathroom. This game feels a little bit in the wrong era. If we were still in the 'xtreme' 90s it may have fit in a little better. Of course if you enjoy base jumping in real life (you crazy madman!) then feel free to ignore all of this and play your heart out!  I see this game being absolutely perfect for its niche, like I say, the completionist extreme sports fan will gleefully be able to spend hours and hours maxing out everything this game has to offer, and good luck to him!  I bet its freaking awesome with the occulus though! If I ever get one I will promise to rewrite this review!
Base jumping is my new solitaire.  I'll give it this, there are a few minor bugs with control; but nothing that has been serious or irreperable so far. For the price, grab it!

This is one of the most challenging, and fun indie-games I have ever played. Seriously makes me envious of people with an Occulus Rift, since this game runs Occulus Rift. Excellent game play, looks beautiful, great soundtrack, and it doesn't hold your hand one bit. Just shows you how the game works and thrusts you in!  The only gripe I have with it, is the parachute controls, since I have died many times trying to land by steering with the mouse, and then going off site and breaking every bone in my body.  Despite the parachute controls, this game controls flawlessly. I would highly recommend for any indie-game enthusiast, and even people who have wanted to base-jump.  10/10!

Excellent game play, looks beautiful, great soundtrack, and it doesn't hold your hand one bit. Just shows you how the game works and thrusts you in!  The only gripe I have with it, is the parachute controls, since I have died many times trying to land by steering with the mouse, and then going off site and breaking every bone in my body.  Despite the parachute controls, this game controls flawlessly. I would highly recommend for any indie-game enthusiast, and even people who have wanted to base-jump.  10/10!

This is one of those games that is so funny/quirky that it's impossible to write a funny/quirky recommendation. Really all I can do is quote the game's intro:   'In the year of our Lord, nineteen eighty two, polystructures fell from space. Massive but light, they touched the atmosphere, and stuck.  Scientists made new materials. Builders made new cities. Families made their homes thousands of feet above ground level. Art made the floating super-sculptures, and culture made the floating caviar socials to regard them.  In the year of our Lord, twenty eleven, you cannot look up from beneath a city and see the stars.  But you can look down from above it. And you can jump.  The jumps you make are not about art. They are about a reckless disregard for safety.  The jumps you make are not about culture. They are about a reckless disregard for regulation.  The jumps you make are not about science. They are about a reckless disregard for gravity.'  And that's the least nutty part of the game.
The levels from the first game are beautifully remastered. One of my favorite twitch games of all time. Get it! It's awesome~

Even though Im not good at this game I love it!! Its got a whimiscal take on those first Skydiving games on older phones, pre smartphone not old smartphones, where you had to fall through hoops to get points. Here you get to fall through flosting buildings, weave in and out of tight spots, and then land. The gameplay is lots of fun and the movement controls are a bit slow, I kind of wish they could be a litle more crisp especially for weaving through the tight spots, but the game was designed to emulate skydiving, so its not really a big surprise.   Pros: Simple controls; Its a fun game  Cons: The movement feels slow to me, but i am NOT good at this game;  For me this game is really fun i would recommend buying this game on sale as 10$ is a little pricey in my books for this kind of game, but then again i am a pretty frugal person, but this game is totally worth a look when its on sale, since you can usually get all of Dejoban games in a collection for super cheap.

So this isn't really a huge leap from the previous one as far as I can tell. Take it with a grain of salt, I only played just a few minutes and didn't feel like I needed to delve too far into it. The biggest improvement I could see was the hit box was shrunk and VR support was added. How many of you actually have a VR device yet? Exactly, neither does anyone else. But the hitbox improvement means you can really thread the needle that much better.  Much of the look is the same though: menus, geometry, effects, pretty much everything. The only difference here is what appears to be newer and more interesting shaders. All-in-all, it's the same as before, and that's a little disappointing. I still recommend it because at it's core, it's fun. However, if you already bought the first one, you might want to wait for this one on sale, or just skip it altogether (unless you really want that VR support). If you didn't get the first one, then this is an easy buy.

This game's really good. Now you may be saying, 'WHY IS THIS?!?!?!', and to that I say 'JEEEEEZUS!' and also the fact that it just is. Maybe it's just that I'm adjusted to flinging myself and my co-workers off of buildings, but it's fun. Now...... I don't know... play..... viju gayms?

This game is awesome, just like it says. It's an adrenaline rush, and it's stupidly fun. It's completely random at times, but the actual gameplay has stunning graphics and great background music. So far no bugs. The controls are fairly good, sometimes they can be tricky when you have to wasd-ctrl-leftclick-rightclick-space all at once, but that doesn't come up often enough to be annoying. Just enough to be challenging. Don't take it too seriously, get past the tutorials and into the fun. Should bear a motion-sickness and epilepsy warning though. Also, turn down the volume before you start, or you might get a nice headphone-blast in the beginning. Totally worth it. I have no regrets.
This game is not too demanding in terms of PC requirements, it also gives you a sense of thrill even without the oculus. but with the rift, you'll just have to scream AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!!
